sn12.66:1.7: Sammasa only appears in one other case in early Pali, at Thag 1.23:1.3. The root is mas (“to rub”), suggesting the idea of examining with the fingers or “to probe”.
sn12.66:3.6: “Attachment” is upadhi, which is both the things of the world to which we cling, and the inner clinging (see Snp 1.2, MN 105:28.2.). The Jains defined upadhi similarly (Tattvārthasūtra 9.26). The dominant meaning in Sanskrit is “fraud”, which perhaps informs the Buddhist sense: the things we attach to give a false sense of security. Here it plays the role of “grasping” (upādāna).
sn12.66:13.10: The drinks are surā (beer), dadhimaṇḍaka (buttermilk or whey), maṭṭhaloṇikā (salted whey or sour cream, i.e. lassi), and loṇasovīraka (salted infusion of fermented barley and herbs). These correspond with drinks mentioned, along with others, in the Cāraka Saṁhita as surā, mastu (Hindi maṭṭhā), dadhimaṇḍa, and sauvīraka. These were fermented drinks used as purgatives, and some or all were also recreational liquors. | Ayaṁ surāpipāsitā pānīyena vā vinetuṁ seems corrupt, read: ayaṁ pipāsā surāpānīyena vā vinetuṁ (“to dispel this thirst by a drink of beer”). | Loṇasovīraka is allowed as medicine (Bu Pj 3:5.33.14, Kd 6:16.3.1; preparation methods are given in Suśruta Saṁhitā 1.44 and commentary to Pj 3). It probably originated in Sovīra (DN 19:36.6). Sanskrit just has sauvīraka but Cāraka Saṁhita 3.1.18 says it can be drunk with salt; salted drinks are still popular in India. It was a great favorite of the hard-partying women of Madra, who, it was said, would sooner part with husband or son than a drop of sauvīraka (Mahābhārata 8.30). | The last phrase is corrupt, read ahitāya dukkhāya following PTS and Bodhi.
